Inspired by questions in #design > Follow Topics and the recent in-person discussion about #design > UI redesign: left sidebar .

I suggest to have recipient bar options be always present and visibly distinctive when a user in such topic view (not an interleaved view):
Recipient bar

And to have all the options appear on hover/focus of recipient bar in an interleaved view.
Later we could improve that by showing all the options in the sticked topic bar of interleaved view (nice idea from @Greg Price )
CleanShot-2023-06-24-at-14.44.07.gif

I tried to remove resolve button when the topic is resolved, but it didn't feel right.
To avoid the layout shift I suggest to replace an arrow ">" with a checkmark icon, which a way of saying "there is nothing to discuss there"
I suggest to indicate a pressed status of resolve button.
image.png
image.png

I tried to have a simple icon of checkmark, closer to what we have now but it didn't loo distinctive enough.
I didn't want it to be of the same size as stream icons 16x16 to misguide the eye and also didn't want to add additional indentation for topics to save horizontal space.
So smaller icon of resolved topic could be distinctive, clear that it is about the topic ands also communicating a status of a topic, not a name change:
image.png
As you can see resolved icons are dimmed here, which reduces their laudness.

Ordering of recipient bar buttons

I'm no sure about the order of buttons. It feels right to have external link right after the name.
I guess resolving is a more frequent action than renaming, but we could flip those buttons back as they are now.
I tried to place mute/unmute/follow buttons before three-dot menu, but later decided to put more button at the end of all.

Let me know what do you think about all that.

Conceptually I think this is working for me. I'm not sure yet about the visual grammar of the audio-like buttons, but as with all such things, it might just take some time playing with and getting used to it.

I also think the indicator for a resolved topic should be stronger somehow--maybe with the same icon but on an inverted background or something? In the mocks here, it's reading to me a little too much like a wayward button.

inverted background or something

That would be too much of an attention. I already feel that in the proposed design is getting more attention than currently.
In the bar not only indicator but the whole pressed button, and in the list of topics it is quite visible.

I'm not sure yet about the visual grammar of the audio-like buttons

In the past these were bells, but visually didn't work great and conceptually we are controlling loudness of the topic, so I think it is working ok. We can change those icons in any time though.

I like the direction of showing the buttons more distinctly at the top, and having them appear on hover in interleaved views (or just for the non-sticky topic bars).

Some thoughts:

1. I don't think replacing the > with a resolved topic icon is working for me. What do other folks think? If we don't want the topic name to move, we might have enough horizontal space to leave a blank spot fo the checkmark instead? Perhaps we could also try making the checkmark before the topic name smaller, since we are also indicating whether or not the topic is resolved on the "resolve topic" button.

I like the idea of having the buttons be more visible on a sticky recipient bar and only visible on hover otherwise, but it feels really busy to me having ~6 buttons worth of stuff in there, and I'm more inclined to push the extra stuff into the 3-dots menu.

I tried to remove resolve button when the topic is resolved, but it didn't feel right.

  1. I think it's good to leave the button there; it makes it easier to undo an accidental resolve.

Alya Abbott said:

  1. I don't think replacing the > with a resolved topic icon is working for me. What do other folks think?

Yeah this isn't particularly working for me either.

I'm no sure about the order of buttons. It feels right to have external link right after the name.

  1. Doing a design pass on the "edit topic" UI might be useful. Currently, when you click the pencil, the pencil button disappears, and the other buttons get pushed to the right. It might feel less natural if the pencil is not adjacent to the topic field. But I think we've talked about hiding all the buttons when the topic is being edited, in which case the button order wouldn't be constrained by that.

Tim Abbott said:

I like the idea of having the buttons be more visible on a sticky recipient bar and only visible on hover otherwise, but it feels really busy to me having ~6 buttons worth of stuff in there, and I'm more inclined to push the extra stuff into the 3-dots menu.

The topic "volume" can just be displayed as a single button showing the current status, which opens a menu to change it (so it's an extra click compared to displaying all the options). (This is likely discussed in some other #design thread, but I'm not caught up.)

Ok, so here is another version and reasoning.
image.png

don't hide '>'

ok, layout shift isn't a big problem, when there are no dangerous actions could be made accidentally.

undo accidental resolve

I thought about it a bit more and I saw the opposite too. When people unresolve. In addition "pressed button" is a bit confusing case and if we can avoid it lets try that.

too many things in the top bar + mute/follow bar is too "heavy"

I don't think we should be afraid of putting things there but at the same time I prefer to not have any other drop downs except the main ⋮ three dot button. Otherwise we have to replicate the functionality of the drop down in 2 places and it is better be the same in both.

Icons which show status are a problem, because they are not buttons. First questions is why you are not a button and how can I tell? And the second is are you showing the current state or a state you will be in when I press. Tab bar is solving that problem...

So if we don't want to have mute/follow bar + we are not sure about icons I suggest we show the status of the topic in words:
MUTED / FOLLOWING / nothing for the default case

If we hide all the bar options and status on hover, we could additionally illustrate the muted topic with a dimmed color:
image.png,

but I guess we do want to show external link button in all cases?

I like the idea of having buttons appear on hover. It helps keep things clear when you don't want to take any actions with the topic. We should also think about adding a delay on hover to avoid showing the buttons when you're just moving the mouse around.

We need to decide how many buttons to show. Personally, I'd prefer if all the possible buttons are available on hover for fast action. But if we want to collapse them, I see three options:

  1. A three-dot popover menu.
  2. An arrow to expand/collapse the buttons.
  3. Horizontal scroll.

All three options are good, but I prefer the collapse/expand button option. It looks visually stylish, can be smoothly animated, and we can store the state so users can expand it if they find it helpful and keep it expanded for the session, at least.

I'm not sure if we should display the muted status using text when we already have all the controls in icons. I find inspiration from the macOS menu bar, where you have all the controls represented by icons and other widgets. The muted or sound state is simply indicated by different icons, and I find it really helpful to have control and easily know the state of things in one place.

All three options are good, but I prefer the collapse/expand button option. It looks visually stylish, can be smoothly animated, and we can store the state so users can expand it if they find it helpful and keep it expanded for the session, at least.

Note that this will not work well for long topic names / mobile where popover menus is the best option.
Thank you for the feedback. Let me think about that again

CleanShot-2023-07-12-at-12.06.34.gif

After some thoughts about this, here is another proposal, which I like more.

  • We show button to resolve and after clicking convert it to unresolve button
  • We indicate resolved topic with an icon + with a dimmed font in the recepient bar
  • current following status is represented behind the icon and to avoid any confusion click on such icon opens a popover with a vertical tab bar
Seem worth deploying and testing it out.
in the more menu I suggest to show all items as we do in the left side bar

I think the overall direction looks good. A few notes:

  • I don't like the icon for "Resolved topic" shown there -- I really think the simple checkmark is a lot clearer than the checkmark inside a circle. It's also awkward to change in the near term even if we prefer something different, since the unicode checkmark character at the start of the topic is what we literally have in the topic name string to indicate a topic is resolved right now. (So without a bunch of work, that unicode character will appear in places like links to the topic).
  • The muted/regular/followed icons idea is great, but I think we need different icons -- the ones we have there are too small and indistinct; I can't easily tell the difference between muted and regular.
  • I think we might want to use a blue/link color for the little "open this link" icons we have to better hint what those are, but am not certain.
The circle-check icon reads too much like a clock with an ambitious minute-hand to me.
Ok, thank you for the feedback, will get back with some response... I can't say that things 100% clear to me...

Update:
recepient-bar-01.png
recepient-bar-02.png
recepient-bar-03.png

About the follow/mute icon: I suggest to get back to the icon which reflects the nature of the property (intensity of notifications, including visually). Bell is an icon about notifications in facebook/youtube/twitter/linkedin

About the checkmark icon: Ok, simplified and I used traditional cross to indicate cancelation/deletion of the check as the way to reverse the actions

About the font based checkmark icon: It is ugly, I don't want to use it. I don't think that the topic should have a different name if its resolved. If there is a desire to pull the icon into resolved topic everywhere it is mentioned this feature should be developed properly. In future there might be other statuses/indicators could be attached to the topic... For example link button could be attached to such topic mention everywhere to jump to an external website. Anyway it's up to you what exactly to do with all this situation.
Bell as an icon seems better to me.

Don't you think that striked bell is a better than bell with a cross?
image.png
Yes, It's more visible than the small cross.
I think "Regular" and "Follow" icons might be confusing? -- They look nearly the same, especially to a new user.
Should we use a variant of '+' icon for "Follow" ?
There is a wording here. Can we try these and reevaluate?

Prakhar Pratyush said:

I think "Regular" and "Follow" icons might be confusing? -- They look nearly the same, especially to a new user.

Yeah, I had the same problem with the new set of icons -- couldn't tell them apart except when looking at them side-by-side.
I think bell as the base icon concept is better, though!

About the font based checkmark icon: It is ugly, I don't want to use it. I don't think that the topic should have a different name if its resolved.

We can consider changing the fact that we're using a unicode checkmark in the topic, but I just want to set expectations that it'd be a big migration involving data model changes that we need to coordinate with the mobile clients. So while I don't think it's necessary that we use the exact same checkmark for it, we probably do want to use a broadly similar one (i.e. not a check inside a box/circle).

I think what you have in the updated designs works well and satisfies that constraint.
Yeah, I don't expect things will be implemented exactly I suggest. It is up to you what to do where because you see tech complexity.

How about a bell with an eye?
image.png
Or a bell with notification dot?
image.png
Prakhar Pratyush mentioned this topic in #design > Follow Topics UI.
I think "bell with notification dot" generally signifies -- "pending notifications"; once I check out those notifications, the dot gets removed.
Also, we might need to have 4 icons here. ref: #design > Follow Topics UI
I didn’t even know that pending notifications is a thing :smile:

Okay i guess "pending notifications" is not a good term to explain :)

LinkedIn

LinkedIn uses a number

Instagram uses a red dot; they have a heart shaped icon.
image.png
image.png
Second image fits the same design, but the first looks larger/clearer?
I don't see a difference between the two other than some cropping?
I think the follow icon/image is slightly different.
Oops. Right you are. Coffee is still kicking in this morning :) Agreed that the first bell looks a little more noisy and urgent
So which one to go with?
My preference is the first...to me it reads much more clearly from silenced bell to normal bell to ringing bell, whereas the second bell adds some additional detail to the bell itself, it seems
The first icon's symmetry is great!
Prakhar Pratyush mentioned this topic in #design > Follow Topics UI.

Just to update this thread. These are the icons decided recently:
popover.png

Thoughts?
Reason for using "eye" with "bell" icon for unmute, discussed here.
They seem OK to me, I think.
Going back to the start of this conversation, I filed In non-sticky recipient header bars, show action buttons only on hover #26852 -- we should at least try it out.
Should I also file an issue for adding the topic three-dot menu to the header bar?

What do folks think about Vlad Korobov 's proposal above for a checkmark with an xfor an unresolved topic? Having the "resolve topic" button reflect the current state would be consistent with how the notifications button works.
I think it's worth exploring. Since a check and an X can mean similar things, I don't know that the X negates the check the way we'd want it to. But reflecting the current state makes sense to me.
Yeah I could also see trying a check with a line through it as an "uncheck" icon; not sure how designable that is.

Tim Abbott said:

Yeah I could also see trying a check with a line through it as an "uncheck" icon; not sure how designable that is.
Reflecting current state on a button is a bad idea

It is always confusing "what would happen if I click?". Notifications icon is a special case I'm not happy about. Nothing tells a user what is going to happen (there is no arrow key, no any other indicator).

In general if we have a regular button which activates one thing the icon should represent what such button is activating
If we want to display the current status then it is a drop down conceptually. And when user clicks it nothing happens (it is safe to just open a dropdown)

Yes, cross on a checkmark isn't great, but it is something different.
I think a user would see that it is something related to resolving the topic but not the usual resolve button:
image.png

With that there is an indicator of resolved on the left side to the name and it is not a button
To somehow fix the situation with notification icon I think we should add a little arrow down on hover, but I don't think it is a feature we should focus on now
Hm, so the proposal to use the checkmark with an x regardless of whether the topic is currently resolved or unresolved?

I think I read it as that's the alternative icon that'd appear if the topic is resolved to give an "unresolve" button, and we'd have the existing checkmark button for topics that are not currently resolved.
